questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bitemporal hemianopia. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Craniopharyngioma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Craniopharyngioma should be considered in young patients presenting with symptoms of visual field loss and a calcified suprasellar mass on imaging. This tumor's characteristic location and calcification are key diagnostic clues.

References:

  • ↳ Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 742

questions.text: The Bragg peak effect is pronounced in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Proton

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Proton beam therapy characteristics:
  • ➤ Proton beam therapy characteristics:
  • ➤ It has marked effect with increased depth in the soft tissues. Bragg's peak is their peculiar feature. Ideal agents for treating deep seated tumors. Agent of choice for treatment of clival chordomas.
  • ➤ It has marked effect with increased depth in the soft tissues.
  • ➤ Bragg's peak is their peculiar feature.
  • ➤ Ideal agents for treating deep seated tumors.
  • ➤ Ideal agents for treating deep seated tumors.
  • ➤ Agent of choice for treatment of clival chordomas.

questions.text: A patient present with Cotton wool skull. Most likely diagnosis is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Paget's disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "cotton wool" appearance of the skull on radiographs is a classic sign of Paget's disease. This pattern results from the chaotic bone remodelling process characteristic of this condition.
  • ➤ The "cotton wool" appearance of the skull on radiographs is a classic sign of Paget's disease.
  • ➤ This pattern results from the chaotic bone remodelling process characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: Steps of surgery of DDH in a child < 2 years:(AIIMS NOV 2019) Capsulotomy Femoral osteotomy Identification of true acetabulum using round ligament Placing the head back into acetabulum
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) a → c → b → d

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • DEVELOPMENTAL DYSPLASIA OF HIP (DDH)
  • • DEVELOPMENTAL DYSPLASIA OF HIP (DDH)
  • • This is a spontaneous dislocation of the hip occurring before, during or shortly after birth. DDH is failure of maintenance of femoral head due to malformations of acetabulum or femur. More common in girls usually seen on left side. Etiology and Pathogenesis: Hereditary predisposition Hormonal factors: High levels of maternal estrogen, progesterone & relax in the last few weeks of pregnancy may aggravate ligamentous laxity in the infant. Breech malposition favors dislocation. It is associated with higher incidence of plagiocephaly and congenital torticollis. Clinical diagnosis:
  • • This is a spontaneous dislocation of the hip occurring before, during or shortly after birth.
  • • DDH is failure of maintenance of femoral head due to malformations of acetabulum or femur.
  • • More common in girls usually seen on left side.
  • • Etiology and Pathogenesis: Hereditary predisposition Hormonal factors: High levels of maternal estrogen, progesterone & relax in the last few weeks of pregnancy may aggravate ligamentous laxity in the infant. Breech malposition favors dislocation. It is associated with higher incidence of plagiocephaly and congenital torticollis.
  • • Etiology and Pathogenesis:
  • • Hereditary predisposition Hormonal factors: High levels of maternal estrogen, progesterone & relax in the last few weeks of pregnancy may aggravate ligamentous laxity in the infant. Breech malposition favors dislocation. It is associated with higher incidence of plagiocephaly and congenital torticollis.
  • • Hereditary predisposition
  • • Hormonal factors: High levels of maternal estrogen, progesterone & relax in the last few weeks of pregnancy may aggravate ligamentous laxity in the infant.
  • • Hormonal factors:
  • • Breech malposition favors dislocation.
  • • It is associated with higher incidence of plagiocephaly and congenital torticollis.
  • • Clinical diagnosis:
  • • Clinical diagnosis:
  • • 1. Barlow’s test:
  • • 1. Barlow’s test:
  • • The examiner grasps the upper part of each thigh, with his fingers behind on the greater trochanter and thumb in front. An attempt is made to lever the femoral head in and out of the acetabulum during abduction and adduction . If femoral head is normally in reduced position but can be made to slip out of the socket & back in again, hip is classed as ‘dislocatable’ (i.e. unstable).
  • • The examiner grasps the upper part of each thigh, with his fingers behind on the greater trochanter and thumb in front.
  • • An attempt is made to lever the femoral head in and out of the acetabulum during abduction and adduction .
  • • femoral head in and out of the acetabulum during abduction and adduction
  • • If femoral head is normally in reduced position but can be made to slip out of the socket & back in again, hip is classed as ‘dislocatable’ (i.e. unstable).
  • • ‘dislocatable’
  • • 2. Ortolani test:
  • • 2. Ortolani test:
  • • This test is similar to the second part of Barlow’s test . The hips and knees are held in a flexed position and gradually abducted. A ‘click of entrance’ will be felt as the femoral head slips into the acetabulum from the position of dislocation.
  • • This test is similar to the second part of Barlow’s test .
  • • similar to the second part of Barlow’s test
  • • The hips and knees are held in a flexed position and gradually abducted.
  • • A ‘click of entrance’ will be felt as the femoral head slips into the acetabulum from the position of dislocation.
  • • ‘click of entrance’
  • • 3. Galeazzi’s sign:
  • • 3. Galeazzi’s sign:
  • • The level of the knees is compared in a child lying with hip flexed to 70° and knees flexed. There is a lowering of the knee on the affected side
  • • The level of the knees is compared in a child lying with hip flexed to 70° and knees flexed.
  • • There is a lowering of the knee on the affected side
  • • 4. Vascular sign of Narath:
  • • 4. Vascular sign of Narath:
  • • The femoral artery pulse is palpated against the femoral head. If very readily palpated: Possible unreduced anterior hip dislocation. If palpated with great difficulty, it implies femoral head displaced from the hip joint due to hip dislocation, most commonly posterior hip dislocation . Imaging:
  • • The femoral artery pulse is palpated against the femoral head.
  • • If very readily palpated: Possible unreduced anterior hip dislocation.
  • • If very readily palpated:
  • • If palpated with great difficulty, it implies femoral head displaced from the hip joint due to hip dislocation, most commonly posterior hip dislocation .
  • • If palpated with great difficulty,
  • • most commonly posterior hip dislocation
  • • Imaging:
  • • Imaging:
  • • Ultrasonography: It is widely used as a screening test for DDH. It has the advantage of demonstrating acetabulum the non-ossified femoral head. Plain Radiograph: Delayed appearance of the ossification centre of the head of the femur. Retarded development of the ossification centre of the head of the femur. Sloping acetabulum Lateral and upward displacement of the ossification centre of the femoral head. A break in Shenton’s line Treatment: Surgical approach: The aim in DDH is to place the head of femur in acetabulum. Open the joint, identify the acetabulum, cut and rotate the femur and place the head in acetabulum. Surgical procedure: Percutaneous adductor tenotomy is performed in all patients prior to open reduction. The hip joint is approached superficially between sartorius and tensor fascia lata. The sartorius is detached from anterior superior iliac spine to improve exposure. The anteromedial capsule is incised to remove the obstacle to reduction. The femoral head is identified and ligamentum teres is cut and traced to the acetabulum. The psoas tendon is identified and tenotomy is done to improve access to the acetabulum. The acetabular labrum is identified and care is taken to keep it intact and undamaged. The transverse acetabular ligament is identified and incised to remove the inferior obstacle to reduction. The acetabulum is cleared of fibrocartilaginous tissue and femoral head is reduced into the acetabulum.
  • • Ultrasonography: It is widely used as a screening test for DDH. It has the advantage of demonstrating acetabulum the non-ossified femoral head.

  • • A break in Shenton’s line

The acetabulum is cleared of fibrocartilaginous tissue and femoral head is reduced into the acetabulum.

  • • The correct order of surgical procedure for DDH in a child < 2 years of age is:

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with a history of pathological fracture of the neck of femur. On lab investigations, ALP and N-telopeptide levels were raised. The DEXA scan confirmed the diagnosis as osteoporosis. Based on the lab values of osteoporosis, which other values will be raised in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tartrate Resistant Acid Phosphatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis due to increased bone resorption, making it a key marker for this condition.
  • ➤ Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP)

questions.text: Match the following : (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A-SVC, B-Aorta, C-Trachea, D-Esophagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When identifying structures on a chest CT, it's crucial to accurately recognize the anatomical positions of key structures like the superior vena cava, aorta, trachea, and esophagus based on their appearance and location in cross-sectional imaging.

questions.text: A child had a fall at home and was treated with an elbow cast. After the removal of the cast, the child developed the deformity as shown. Which fracture most likely caused this deformity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Supracondylar humerus fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cubitus varus , a "gunstock" deformity, is a classic complication of malunited supracondylar humerus fractures in children, where the carrying angle is reduced, causing medial deviation of the arm.
  • ➤ Cubitus varus
  • ➤ supracondylar humerus fractures

questions.text: A 75-year-old female had a fall and had intertrochanteric fracture. This is due to:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Osteoporosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hip fractures are most commonly seen in elderly females due to osteoporosis.
  • ➤ Hip fractures are most commonly seen in elderly females due to osteoporosis.

questions.text: During excision of ranula along with sublingual gland, which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lingual nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During the excision of a ranula and the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is the structure most likely to be injured due to its anatomical position relative to the sublingual gland. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and its injury can result in significant sensory deficits.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chronic SDH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A crescent or moon-shaped, hypodense (dark) collection on a CT scan suggests a chronic subdural hematoma (SDH).

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by periosteal thickening, sclerosis, and central lucency within the bone, which are key diagnostic features visible on imaging.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chiari malformation is diagnosed by the inferior displacement of the cerebellar tonsils below the foramen magnum, typically more than 5 mm, seen on imaging.

questions.text: Which muscle is affected if the patient is unable to make an "OK" sign? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Flexor pollicis longus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The flexor pollicis longus is essential for making the "OK" sign, and its impairment is a key clinical feature of anterior interosseous nerve damage.

questions.text: Which of the following tests are used for the evaluation of scoliosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bending forward

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scoliosis curve evaluation is done by forward bending test/Adam’s test. A structural scoliotic curve becomes more prominent on forward bending while the postural curve disappears.
  • ➤ Scoliosis curve evaluation is done by forward bending test/Adam’s test.
  • ➤ A structural scoliotic curve becomes more prominent on forward bending while the postural curve disappears.

questions.text: A child presents with left to right shunt and high output cardiac failure. The following is his MRI. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Vein of Galen malformation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vein of Galen malformation is a critical diagnosis to consider in infants presenting with signs of high-output cardiac failure, and it can be identified with specific imaging findings such as large flow voids on MRI indicative of abnormal vascular connections.

questions.text: Which type of translocation is seen in diaphyseal tumor with small blue round cells? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) T11, 22

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The t(11;22) translocation is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma , a diaphyseal tumor with small, round, blue cells, making it a crucial genetic marker for diagnosis.
  • ➤ t(11;22) translocation
  • ➤ Ewing's sarcoma

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior rib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior rib appears as a horizontal structure on a chest X-ray, distinguishing it from the more curved anterior ribs and other thoracic structures.

questions.text: A construction worker sustained a head injury from a hammer falling on his head. The CT scan image is shown as below. What is the diagnosis ?(FMGE 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Depressed skull fracture

questions.text: Diagnose the condition shown in the following image. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic Osteomyelitis is characterized by long-standing infection, typically with a chronic clinical course and imaging findings that reflect bone destruction and chronic inflammation. The given image in the question shows sequestrum and involucrum in the lower end of femur, which are typically characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis.
  • ➤ Chronic Osteomyelitis is characterized by long-standing infection, typically with a chronic clinical course and imaging findings that reflect bone destruction and chronic inflammation.
  • ➤ The given image in the question shows sequestrum and involucrum in the lower end of femur, which are typically characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: Identify the given sign:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Popeye sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image shown in the question is called Popeye Sign, which is visible on elbow flexion due to bicipital tendonitis.
  • ➤ The image shown in the question is called Popeye Sign, which is visible on elbow flexion due to bicipital tendonitis.

questions.text: Name the investigation shown in the given image? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Conventional HSG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conventional HSG is a critical diagnostic tool in the assessment of uterine structure and tubal patency, using a radiopaque dye visualized with fluoroscopy, particularly useful in the workup of infertility.

questions.text: A young female patient complains of low back pain radiating to the right hip, back of the thigh, leg, and ankle after an intense workout of lifting some heavy weights. MRI shows the following finding. Which nerve root is most likely to be involved here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) L5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an L4-L5 disc prolapse , the L5 nerve root is most commonly compressed, causing pain radiating down the back of the thigh and into the leg and ankle.
  • ➤ L4-L5 disc prolapse
  • ➤ L5 nerve root

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aberrant right subclavian artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variant where the artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and courses posterior to the esophagus, often leading to dysphagia lusoria due to esophageal compression.

questions.text: Non-articular bone pain is differentiated from articular bone pain by:(NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Pain in both active and passive movements

questions.correct_answer: B. Pain in only active movements
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pain in only active movements

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-articular pain occurs only during active movements. When both active and passive range of movements are painful, it is due to articular pain.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with chronic low back pain. CT scan of the lower back showed the following. Diagnose the condition CT scan image shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Spondylolisthesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spondylolisthesis involves the slipping of one vertebra over another, typically visualized in imaging studies. The "beheaded dog" or "Scottish terrier sign" is a key radiographic feature of this condition.

questions.text: Intermittent dose of Parathyroid hormone causes risk of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteosarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteosarcoma have indicated a potential risk with continuous and intermittent PTH administration, though it is rarely seen complication of intermittent PTH therapy.
  • ➤ Osteosarcoma have indicated a potential risk with continuous and intermittent PTH administration, though it is rarely seen complication of intermittent PTH therapy.

questions.text: A football player had a twisting injury of the knee with no clinical bony injury. Which test is being performed here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lachman’s test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lachman’s test is the most reliable physical exam maneuver for diagnosing ACL tears, performed with the knee in 20-30 degrees of flexion.

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. The post-op x-ray is shown below. The fracture will heal by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Primary healing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary healing occurs with rigid fixation (such as plating) and involves direct bone formation without callus formation. Secondary healing involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion, typically seen with casts or nailing.
  • ➤ Primary healing occurs with rigid fixation (such as plating) and involves direct bone formation without callus formation.

questions.text: Bone mineral density screening is recommended after the age of:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 65 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bone mineral density screening by DEXA scan is recommended at the age more than 65 years.
  • ➤ Bone mineral density screening by DEXA scan is recommended at the age more than 65 years.

questions.text: What is the preferred diagnostic investigation for a patient presenting with this finding? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Duplex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Duplex ultrasound is highly effective for diagnosing conditions affecting the blood vessels, like venous insufficiency, because it can directly visualize both the anatomy of the blood vessels and the movement of blood through them.
  • ➤ Duplex ultrasound is highly effective for diagnosing conditions affecting the blood vessels, like venous insufficiency, because it can directly visualize both the anatomy of the blood vessels and the movement of blood through them.

questions.text: Which tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus on inversion of the foot? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Posterior tibialis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during inversion of the foot and inserts on the navicular bone.

questions.text: Identify: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Venous ulcers are typically found on the medial aspect of the lower leg, above the medial malleolus, and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. Recognizing their characteristic location and appearance is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st CMC with sparing of wrist and MCP is seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Osteoarthritis

questions.text: While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hoover’s sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as Hoover’s sign .
  • ➤ Hoover’s sign

questions.text: A patient who used to work out regularly at the gym gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. AVN of hip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pain in the hip aggravated while squatting with history of regular use of steroid over last six months, flattening of femoral head and presence of subchondral cysts on X-ray are suggestive of AVN of the hip.
  • ➤ Pain in the hip aggravated while squatting with history of regular use of steroid over last six months, flattening of femoral head and presence of subchondral cysts on X-ray are suggestive of AVN of the hip.

questions.text: Identify the sign. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Double ring sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "double ring sign" on an X-ray is characteristic of a button battery, easily distinguishable by its unique appearance.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given image? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Unicornuate uterus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unicornuate uterus is identified on HSG by a fusiform shape and a single fallopian tube connection, often displaced from the midline, indicating unilateral Müllerian duct development.

questions.text: Identify the image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fluoroscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluoroscopy is a dynamic X-ray imaging technique used to visualize the motion of the pharynx and esophagus during swallowing. It provides real-time assessment, unlike a static barium swallow.

questions.text: Sprengel’s deformity associated with all except: (INICET Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Dextrocardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dextrocardia is rarely associated with Sprengel’s Deformity.

questions.text: Hyperextension at MCP joint and flexion at IP joint occurs due to involvement of which muscle?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Lumbricals and interossei

questions.text: Evaluate the following statements with respect to CTEV.(AIIMS NOV 2019) 50% cases are in males and are bilateral Forefoot is adducted and supinated With Ponsetti technique, correction is up to 90% Equinus should be corrected first

options.label: D
options.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.correct_answer: A. a, b, c are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. a, b, c are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In CTEV, male children are more affected than females. 50% of cases of CTEV have bilateral lower limb involvement. There is forefoot adduction and supination in cases of CTEV. Ponseti method of conservative treatment gives correction of up to 90%.
  • ➤ In CTEV, male children are more affected than females.
  • ➤ In CTEV, male children are more affected than females.
  • ➤ 50% of cases of CTEV have bilateral lower limb involvement.
  • ➤ 50% of cases of CTEV have bilateral lower limb involvement.
  • ➤ There is forefoot adduction and supination in cases of CTEV.
  • ➤ There is forefoot adduction and supination in cases of CTEV.
  • ➤ Ponseti method of conservative treatment gives correction of up to 90%.
  • ➤ Ponseti method of conservative treatment gives correction of up to 90%.
  • ➤ Equinus deformity is corrected at last, following the C-A-V-E sequence.

questions.text: A child presented with the following deformity and history of recurrent tooth abscess. On lab investigation, his serum calcium was normal, serum phosphorus was normal/reduced, serum PTH was normal, and ALP was increased. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A)  Hypophosphatemic rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by normal PTH levels, normal/reduced phosphorus levels, and increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP). If PTH is normal in a case of suspected rickets, hypophosphatemic rickets should be strongly considered.
  • ➤ Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by normal PTH levels, normal/reduced phosphorus levels, and increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP).

questions.text: A patient underwent endoscopy, during the procedure perforation occurred at 25 cm from the incisors. Which structure is likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arch of aorta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perforation at 25 cm from the incisors during endoscopy is most likely to involve the arch of the aorta due to its anatomical position relative to the esophagus.

questions.text: Which movement of the hip is being demonstrated by the examiner in the following diagram?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Internal rotation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows internal rotation of hip.
  • ➤ The given image shows internal rotation of hip.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presented in clinic with low back pain & stiffness since 2 months. Modified Schober's test done was positive. An X-ray was done as shown in the image. Most likely diagnosis is:(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image in the question shows the bamboo spine appearance which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis. Out of the diagnostic criterias for ankylosing spondylitis, one of the criteria is the positive modified Schober’s test i.e., limited lumbar spine movement in saggital and frontal planes.
  • ➤ The given image in the question shows the bamboo spine appearance which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • ➤ Out of the diagnostic criterias for ankylosing spondylitis, one of the criteria is the positive modified Schober’s test i.e., limited lumbar spine movement in saggital and frontal planes.

questions.text: A patient presenting with headaches, hypertension, and elevated metanephrines should undergo which diagnostic investigation? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) MIBG scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Diagnostic investigation of choice for pheochromocytoma is MIBG scan.
  • ➤ Diagnostic investigation of choice for pheochromocytoma is MIBG scan.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the arrow?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Superior mesenteric vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Superior Mesenteric Vein can be distinguished on a CT scan by its position to the right of the Superior Mesenteric Artery, and its relation to the uncinate process. Remembering "SMAL" (Superior Mesenteric Artery Left, Superior Mesenteric Vein Right) can aid in identification during diagnostic imaging.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female underwent hip replacement. After 1 year, she developed fever and pain in the joint. Radiograph revealed loosening of prosthesis. The implant had to be removed. The histological image of the tissue adjoining the implant is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Metallosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image in the question shows extracellular metal deposits (black deposits) surrounded by inflammatory cells, suggestive of metallosis. It is associated with metal-on-metal prosthetic devices.
  • ➤ The image in the question shows extracellular metal deposits (black deposits) surrounded by inflammatory cells, suggestive of metallosis.
  • ➤ It is associated with metal-on-metal prosthetic devices.

questions.text: What is the use of the given instrument?

options.label: B
options.text: To hold bone fragments with traction

options.label: D
options.text: For creating a gap in wound

questions.correct_answer: B. To hold bone fragments with traction
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) To hold bone fragments with traction.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • BONE HOLDING FORCEPS
  • • BONE HOLDING FORCEPS
  • • Bone holding forceps are used to manipulate bone fragments in place during surgery. They are typically used in orthopedic procedures, such as the repair of fractures or the realignment of bones. These forceps are designed to grip the bone securely without damaging it, and can be adjusted to apply the appropriate amount of force to hold the bone in the desired position.
  • • Bone holding forceps are used to manipulate bone fragments in place during surgery.
  • • They are typically used in orthopedic procedures, such as the repair of fractures or the realignment of bones.
  • • These forceps are designed to grip the bone securely without damaging it, and can be adjusted to apply the appropriate amount of force to hold the bone in the desired position.
  • • They allow for more precise manipulation of the bones during surgery and can help ensure the success of the procedure.
  • • They allow for more precise manipulation of the bones during surgery and can help ensure the success of the procedure.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. To hold bone and plate . For this purpose, a Bone-Plate Holding Forcep is used. They are designed to aid in the reduction of fractures and can help secure a plate in place during installation . Aid in the reduction of fractures such as spiral, transverse, compound, oblique, or butterfly. The clamp can also be used to secure a plate in place while the screw holes are being drilled and screws inserted. The fracture site can also be manipulated with the clamp being used as a lever. It has teeth in the jaws for a better grip and a ratchet locking handle for use on various bone diameters.
  • • Option A. To hold bone and plate
  • • Option C. To cut the bone . For this purpose, a Bone Cutter is used.
  • • Option C. To cut the bone
  • • Option D. For creating a gap in wound. Wound Spreader is a specialized device that is used to grasp, retract and manipulate the edges of wounds and incisions, in order to spread the space between them and localize surgical targets with ease.
  • • Option D.
  • • For creating a gap in wound. Wound Spreader

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To hold the bone with traction during the surgical procedure, a Bone Holding Forcep is used.
  • ➤ To hold the bone with traction during the surgical procedure, a Bone Holding Forcep is used.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with knee pain following a fall from the stairs. The physical and radiological evaluation revealed injury to the marked structure. Identify the structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tibial tuberosity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The tibial tuberosity is the site of attachment for the patellar ligament, and injuries to this region, particularly in young individuals, can result in conditions such as Osgood-Schlatter disease , characterized by pain at the site, especially following physical activity or trauma.
  • ➤ tibial tuberosity
  • ➤ Osgood-Schlatter disease

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic pancreatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by pancreatic calcifications on imaging, which are absent in acute pancreatitis and other conditions like Wolman disease or TB.

questions.text: The longitudinal growth of the bone is affected by fracture of which region of the bone? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Epiphyseal plate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The epiphyseal plate is the region of the bone responsible for longitudinal growth, and fractures affecting this area can have significant implications on the bone's growth and development.
  • ➤ epiphyseal plate

questions.text: In context of biliary atresia, what is the typical duration of jaundice observed in infants? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Persistent jaundice extending beyond two weeks of age in an infant can be indicative of biliary atresia and warrants prompt investigation and potential surgical intervention.

questions.text: Haglund’s deformity is seen in which joint?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ankle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Haglund deformity is seen at the ankle joint.
  • ➤ Haglund deformity is seen at the ankle joint.

questions.text: Diagnose the X-ray as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Osteosarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sun ray appearance and Codman’s triangle in X-rays are key indicators of osteosarcoma, especially in the lower end of long bones like the femur.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the MRCP image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Choledochal cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fusiform dilatation of the common bile duct on MRCP is characteristic of a Type 1 choledochal cyst, the most common type of choledochal cyst.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the CT image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PUJO (Pelviureteric Junction Obstruction)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PUJO is characterized by massive dilation of the renal pelvis with thinning of the renal parenchyma due to obstruction at the pelviureteric junction. The pelvis is more dilated than the calyces, which is a hallmark finding on imaging.

questions.text: A lady presented with a pelvic mass which was hyperintense on T1-weighted image, hyperintense on T1-fat saturated image, and hypointense on T2-weighted image with T2 shading. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endometrioma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endometriomas are characterized by T1 hyperintensity that persists on T1-fat saturated images and display the T2 shading sign, distinguishing them from other ovarian masses.

questions.text: A female present with pain and swelling over multiple peripheral small joints and deformity as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid Arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image in the question shows swan neck deformity, which is characteristic of Rheumatoid Arthritis.
  • ➤ The image in the question shows swan neck deformity, which is characteristic of Rheumatoid Arthritis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with long standing history of back pain for 20 years and chest tightness. Lateral radiograph of the cervical spine is shown. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) DISH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given x-ray image shows DISH i.e., diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, which is the non-inflammatory disease, with calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the enthuses, mainly at the thoracic spine.
  • ➤ The given x-ray image shows DISH i.e., diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, which is the non-inflammatory disease, with calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the enthuses, mainly at the thoracic spine.
